Energy storage costs decline gradually to $75-100/kWh by 2050
Natural gas serves as extended bridge fuel in Asia and Africa through 2045
Climate finance commitments remain underfunded at 40-60% of pledged amounts
Global economic growth averages 2-3% annually without major disruptions

raw_scenarios.name: Fossil Fuel Resilience
raw_scenarios.description: Strong incumbent resistance, geopolitical instability, and slower-than-expected technology progress allow fossil fuels to maintain dominant market position. New natural gas discoveries and carbon capture investments enable continued hydrocarbon use while renewable adoption stalls at moderate levels.
key_assumptions: Major fossil fuel producers successfully lobby against aggressive climate policies through 2040
Battery storage costs remain above $100/kWh due to lithium supply constraints and limited alternatives
Large-scale carbon capture achieves commercial viability, legitimizing continued fossil fuel use
Global conflicts or recession in 2027-2030 deprioritizes climate spending
Nuclear renaissance fails due to cost overruns and public opposition

raw_scenarios.name: Climate Emergency Response
raw_scenarios.description: Catastrophic climate events in the late 2020s and 2030s trigger emergency international mobilization comparable to wartime efforts. Governments mandate rapid renewable deployment through massive subsidies, fossil fuel phase-outs, and coordinated industrial policy, achieving unprecedented transformation speed.
key_assumptions: Multiple 1-in-100-year climate disasters occur between 2027-2035, galvanizing political will
Global carbon tax or cap-and-trade system implemented by 2032 with $150+/ton pricing
Governments provide $500+ billion annually in renewable energy subsidies and infrastructure
Fossil fuel extraction banned or heavily restricted in most jurisdictions by 2040
Wartime-scale industrial mobilization prioritizes renewable manufacturing and deployment

raw_scenarios.name: Nuclear Renaissance Hybrid
raw_scenarios.description: A resurgence of nuclear power driven by small modular reactors and fusion breakthroughs complements renewables, creating a low-carbon energy mix where nuclear handles baseload while renewables provide variable generation. This dual approach moderates renewable share while accelerating decarbonization.
key_assumptions: Small modular reactors achieve commercial deployment at scale by 2033-2035
Fusion energy reaches commercial pilot projects by 2040-2042 with promising economics
Nuclear regulatory frameworks streamline globally, reducing construction times to 4-6 years
Public opinion shifts favorably toward nuclear after 2028 due to climate urgency
Combined nuclear and renewables reach 75-85% of energy mix, with renewables at 45-55%

raw_scenarios.name: Quantum Biology Revolution
raw_scenarios.description: Quantum computing breakthroughs enable molecular-level simulation of DNA sequences, eliminating the need for traditional physical sequencing. By 2040, quantum sensors can read genetic information through non-invasive electromagnetic scanning, making sequencing nearly instantaneous and virtually free.
key_assumptions: Quantum computing achieves fault-tolerant operation by 2032, enabling complex biological simulations
Quantum sensing technology matures to detect single-molecule DNA configurations
Major tech companies invest heavily in quantum biology infrastructure
Regulatory frameworks rapidly adapt to approve quantum-based diagnostic methods
Manufacturing costs for quantum sensors drop below $10,000 per unit by 2045

raw_scenarios.name: Commoditized Nanopore Sequencing
raw_scenarios.description: Nanopore sequencing technology becomes as ubiquitous and cheap as USB drives. Disposable, single-use sequencing chips are manufactured at semiconductor-scale volumes, integrated into consumer health devices and routine medical screenings worldwide.
key_assumptions: Oxford Nanopore and competitors achieve sub-$1 per chip manufacturing costs through mass production
Sequencing accuracy reaches 99.999% for nanopore technology, matching or exceeding Illumina standards
Smartphones and wearable devices incorporate sequencing capabilities as standard features
Global supply chains for biological sensors stabilize, with multiple manufacturers competing
Cloud-based analysis reduces per-genome computational costs to negligible levels

raw_scenarios.name: Stagnation and Consolidation
raw_scenarios.description: After initial rapid progress, sequencing costs plateau due to market consolidation, regulatory burdens, and lack of breakthrough innovations. A few dominant players control the market, maintaining prices above marginal costs to protect profit margins and R&D investments.
key_assumptions: Patent thickets and intellectual property disputes slow innovation between 2028-2040
Stringent privacy regulations increase compliance costs for sequencing providers
Market consolidates to 2-3 major players who coordinate on pricing
Demand remains primarily clinical rather than becoming consumer-driven
No major technological paradigm shift occurs beyond incremental improvements to existing methods

raw_scenarios.name: Synthetic Biology Disruption
raw_scenarios.description: Advances in synthetic biology and cellular engineering create living biosensors that can sequence DNA using engineered cellular machinery at essentially zero marginal cost. Bioengineered organisms become the sequencing infrastructure, reproducing and maintaining themselves.
key_assumptions: CRISPR and gene editing tools enable precise design of cellular sequencing systems by 2033
Biocontainment and safety protocols allow widespread deployment of engineered organisms
Cellular sequencers achieve accuracy comparable to electronic methods
Public acceptance of synthetic biology grows significantly
Biomanufacturing scales to produce billions of cellular sequencing units annually

raw_scenarios.name: Geopolitical Fragmentation
raw_scenarios.description: Global tensions and data sovereignty concerns fragment the sequencing market into regional blocs with different technological standards and cost structures. Western nations face higher costs due to strict regulations and supply chain disruptions, while other regions develop alternative lower-cost approaches.
key_assumptions: US-China technology decoupling extends to biotech and genomics sectors by 2030
Regional data localization laws prevent economies of scale in cloud analysis
Supply chain disruptions for rare materials increase hardware costs in some markets
Parallel technology standards emerge, reducing interoperability and increasing costs
Military and national security applications drive government subsidies unevenly across regions

raw_scenarios.name: AI-Driven Cost Collapse
raw_scenarios.description: Artificial intelligence systems design entirely new sequencing methods that are orders of magnitude cheaper than current approaches. AI discovers novel physics-based techniques and optimizes every aspect of the sequencing pipeline, from sample preparation to data analysis.
key_assumptions: AGI or highly capable AI systems emerge by 2035 and focus on scientific problems
AI-designed sequencing methods require minimal physical infrastructure
Machine learning reduces error rates to near-zero, eliminating expensive redundancy
Automated labs and robotic systems handle all sample processing
AI-optimized supply chains and manufacturing drive component costs to theoretical minimums

raw_scenarios.name: Orbital Manufacturing Boom
raw_scenarios.description: Dramatic cost reductions in launch services and advances in zero-gravity manufacturing create a thriving orbital industrial complex. Space-based fabrication of semiconductors, pharmaceuticals, and specialized materials becomes cost-competitive with terrestrial production by the 2030s, with multiple private space stations operating as factories.
key_assumptions: SpaceX Starship and competing heavy-lift systems reduce launch costs to under $100/kg by 2030
Zero-gravity manufacturing proves 10-100x more efficient for high-value materials like fiber optics and protein crystals
International regulatory frameworks enable streamlined commercial orbital operations
Private investment in orbital infrastructure exceeds $500 billion between 2026-2040
Energy costs for space operations drop significantly through improved solar power and nuclear systems

raw_scenarios.name: Stagnation and Setbacks
raw_scenarios.description: Multiple catastrophic failures, geopolitical conflicts, and persistent economic challenges stall the space industry's growth. Public support wanes after several high-profile accidents, and launch costs remain stubbornly high due to technological plateaus and regulatory burdens.
key_assumptions: Major space disasters between 2028-2035 kill hundreds and trigger strict international regulations
Reusable rocket technology hits diminishing returns with costs stabilizing around $1,000-2,000/kg
Earth-based alternatives (advanced materials, terrestrial solar) prove more economical than anticipated
Kessler syndrome events in LEO severely limit orbital access and increase insurance costs
Space remains primarily government-funded with minimal commercial profitability outside communications

raw_scenarios.name: Lunar Resource Rush
raw_scenarios.description: Discovery of economically viable helium-3, rare earth elements, and water ice deposits triggers a lunar mining boom by 2035. Competition among nations and corporations to establish permanent lunar bases drives unprecedented investment in cislunar infrastructure and space-based logistics.
key_assumptions: Confirmed lunar deposits worth trillions enable positive ROI for mining operations by 2038
Fusion power breakthroughs make helium-3 commercially valuable by 2040
At least 5 nations establish permanent lunar bases between 2032-2045
Cislunar economy generates $2+ trillion annually by 2050 in mining, refining, and transport
Point-to-point Earth rocket transport becomes viable, using lunar-sourced propellant

raw_scenarios.name: Space Solar Dominance
raw_scenarios.description: Space-based solar power achieves breakthrough economics through robotic assembly and wireless power transmission. By 2045, orbital solar arrays provide 15-25% of Earth's electricity, with massive constellations of power satellites representing trillions in space-based capital.
key_assumptions: Wireless power transmission efficiency reaches 60-70% through microwave or laser technologies
Automated robotic systems can construct gigawatt-scale solar arrays in orbit by 2038
Global energy demand grows 50-80% by 2050, with terrestrial renewables facing land-use constraints
Carbon pricing and climate pressures make space solar cost-competitive by 2035
International agreements enable safe microwave transmission corridors through atmosphere

raw_scenarios.name: Modest Communications Growth
raw_scenarios.description: The space economy grows steadily but incrementally, dominated by satellite communications, Earth observation, and GPS services. Space remains primarily a service sector supporting terrestrial activities rather than generating independent productive capital.
key_assumptions: Launch costs decline moderately to $300-500/kg, enabling larger constellations but not heavy industry
Mega-constellations for internet and IoT reach 50,000+ satellites but commoditize with thin margins
Space tourism and entertainment grow to $50-100 billion annually but remain niche markets
Manufacturing and mining in space prove economically unviable before 2050 due to complexity
Space contributes 0.5-2% of global GDP, similar to aviation industry's role today

raw_scenarios.name: AI-Enabled Space Expansion
raw_scenarios.description: Artificial general intelligence and advanced robotics revolutionize space operations by 2035, enabling autonomous construction of massive orbital facilities and asteroid mining at previously impossible scales. AI systems design and build space infrastructure with minimal human oversight.
key_assumptions: AGI achieved by 2032 enables superintelligent optimization of space systems
Self-replicating robotic systems use asteroid materials to build exponentially growing infrastructure
Human presence in space becomes optional as AI handles complex operations
Space-based computing facilities leverage extreme cold and radiation-hardened AI chips
Autonomous systems capture and process near-Earth asteroids worth quadrillions in materials

global_scenarios.name: Resilient Progress
global_scenarios.description: Despite periodic shocks including regional conflicts, moderate pandemics, economic crises, and climate pressures, international cooperation and technological progress prove sufficient to prevent catastrophic outcomes. Incremental improvements in governance, healthcare, and adaptation enable continued development with manageable setbacks.
key_drivers: International institutions maintain functionality for coordinating global threat responses
Medical countermeasures can be developed and distributed within 12-24 months for novel threats
Nuclear deterrence and arms control frameworks hold despite periodic crises
Climate adaptation investments prevent synchronized global failures
Democratic governance expands or stabilizes with functional institutions

global_scenarios.name: Fragmented Multipolar World
global_scenarios.description: Rising geopolitical tensions fragment the global order into competing spheres of influence with distinct economic systems, technological standards, and governance models. US-China decoupling accelerates into broader multipolar economic fragmentation, reducing trade flows, duplicating supply chains, and limiting technology transfer while defense spending increases substantially.
key_drivers: US-China strategic competition intensifies with significant economic decoupling by 2035
Global trade as percentage of GDP declines 20-30% from 2025 levels
Technology ecosystems split into 2-3 incompatible standards across AI, internet, and payments
Regional blocs deepen internal integration while cross-bloc cooperation stalls
Defense spending increases to 3-4% of GDP in major economies

global_scenarios.name: Secular Stagnation
global_scenarios.description: Multiple headwinds converge to create prolonged low-growth resembling Japan's lost decades but at global scale. Aging demographics, declining productivity growth, high debt burdens, and political gridlock prevent major reforms. Real interest rates remain near zero, limiting monetary policy effectiveness while structural problems persist unaddressed.
key_drivers: Global population peaks around 2045-2048 with rapid aging in major economies
Total factor productivity growth remains below 1% annually through 2050
Government debt levels exceed 150-200% of GDP in most developed economies by 2040
Political polarization prevents implementation of structural reforms
Labor force participation declines as demographics worsen and discouraged workers exit

global_scenarios.name: Climate Catastrophe
global_scenarios.description: Accelerating climate change triggers cascading failures across food systems, water resources, and human habitats. Multiple tipping points converge between 2032-2045, causing synchronized crop failures, mass displacement of populations, expanded disease vectors, and resource conflicts. Adaptation efforts prove insufficient as climate impacts outpace mitigation measures.
key_drivers: Global temperatures rise 2.5-3.5°C above pre-industrial levels by 2040-2050
Multiple climate tipping points cascade including agricultural collapse and extreme weather
Climate-induced migration exceeds 200+ million people creating humanitarian crises
Water scarcity affects 3+ billion people triggering resource wars
International cooperation on climate finance and adaptation fails to meet needs

global_scenarios.name: AI-Driven Prosperity
global_scenarios.description: Artificial intelligence and automation drive unprecedented productivity gains across all sectors, successfully managing workforce transitions while creating new industries and human-AI collaborative roles. AI augments rather than replaces human capabilities, extending working years and enabling breakthrough scientific discoveries that accelerate progress in medicine, energy, and materials science.
key_drivers: AGI or highly capable AI systems developed and safely deployed by 2035-2045
AI serves primarily as complementary technology enhancing human productivity
Successful social adaptation to rapid technological change with minimal disruption
AI-driven scientific breakthroughs in healthcare, energy, and biotechnology
Effective governance frameworks manage AI risks while enabling innovation

global_scenarios.name: Techno-Oligarchy
global_scenarios.description: AI and automation create winner-take-all dynamics where technology conglomerates and capital owners capture unprecedented economic value. Wealth concentration reaches extreme levels as returns to capital dominate returns to labor, while regulatory frameworks fail to prevent monopolistic consolidation or implement effective redistribution mechanisms.
key_drivers: AI development leads to massive productivity gains captured primarily by capital owners
Regulatory frameworks fail to prevent monopolistic consolidation in tech and AI sectors
Traditional wealth redistribution mechanisms remain unimplemented or easily circumvented
Digital assets and platforms enable new forms of wealth concentration and preservation
Labor bargaining power erodes dramatically as automation reduces worker leverage

global_scenarios.name: Nuclear Deterrence Holds
global_scenarios.description: Despite periodic crises and close calls, nuclear deterrence fundamentally maintains strategic stability through 2050. Arms control frameworks are renewed, accidental launch safeguards improve, and nuclear-armed states recognize mutual vulnerability prevents rational use. Proliferation remains limited with small arsenals.
key_drivers: Major powers maintain credible second-strike capability and stable deterrence
Arms control treaties renewed or replaced with functional equivalents maintaining stability
Close calls and crises resolved through diplomatic channels and military-to-military communication
Nuclear modernization prioritizes safety and negative control over first-strike capability
Non-proliferation regime prevents additional states from acquiring weapons or limits arsenal sizes

global_scenarios.name: Green Transition Surge
global_scenarios.description: Massive coordinated investment in clean energy, circular economy principles, and climate adaptation creates a new industrial revolution. Breakthrough cost reductions in renewables and storage enable complete grid transformation while green technology exports become major growth drivers. Climate damage costs stabilize through successful mitigation efforts.
key_drivers: Renewable energy costs decline 60-70% enabling complete grid transformation by 2045
Global carbon pricing or equivalent policies implemented covering 80%+ of emissions by 2035
Breakthrough in energy storage and green hydrogen enables industrial decarbonization
Federal climate investment reaches $300-500 billion annually creating millions of jobs
Green technology sectors capture 30-40% of global export markets

global_scenarios.name: Biotech Renaissance
global_scenarios.description: Breakthroughs in biotechnology, longevity medicine, synthetic biology, and gene therapies transform human health and productivity. Anti-aging treatments extend healthy working years by 10-25 years, CRISPR eliminates genetic diseases, and AI-accelerated drug discovery creates treatments for previously incurable conditions. Agricultural productivity surges through precision farming and synthetic biology.
key_drivers: Medical advances extend healthy lifespan and working years significantly by 2045
Senolytic drugs and regenerative medicine achieve clinical approval by early 2030s
Gene editing therapies eliminate major genetic diseases and enable personalized medicine
AI-driven drug discovery reduces development time from 10+ years to 3-4 years
Synthetic biology doubles agricultural productivity and creates new biomanufacturing industries

global_scenarios.name: Labor Displacement Era
global_scenarios.description: Rapid AI and automation advancement eliminates jobs faster than new ones are created, particularly in transportation, manufacturing, retail, and administrative sectors. Traditional development pathways through labor-intensive industry become obsolete. Universal basic income or expanded safety nets support growing non-employed population.
key_drivers: AI systems automate 40-60% of current jobs by 2040 across both manual and cognitive tasks
Developing countries lose competitive advantage in labor-intensive manufacturing
Educational systems fail to retrain workers quickly enough for new skill requirements
Labor force participation rates decline significantly as workers exit permanently
Social acceptance grows for non-employment lifestyles with UBI or similar support

global_scenarios.name: Great Power Conflict
global_scenarios.description: Major armed conflict erupts between nuclear powers or their proxies, potentially involving Taiwan, Eastern Europe, or resource competition. Conventional warfare escalates with possibility of limited nuclear use, AI-accelerated weapons deployment, or cyber-physical infrastructure attacks. Casualties reach millions with widespread economic disruption and societal breakdown.
key_drivers: Regional tensions escalate to military confrontation between major powers by 2035-2040
AI integration into military systems compresses decision timelines and increases accident risk
Nuclear deterrence partially fails with tactical weapons use or accidents during crisis
Autonomous weapons systems and cyber capabilities undermine strategic stability
Climate-driven resource scarcity intensifies competition over water, food, and territory

global_scenarios.name: AI-Enabled Authoritarianism
global_scenarios.description: Advanced AI surveillance and control systems enable unprecedented authoritarian governance that proves difficult or impossible to overthrow. Digital totalitarianism spreads as regimes demonstrate sustained economic performance while suppressing dissent through AI-optimized social control, creating stable but oppressive political systems.
key_drivers: AI-powered surveillance and social control systems allow preemption of opposition movements
China's governance model gains influence demonstrating economic success with authoritarian stability
Democratic institutions weaken due to polarization, misinformation, and dysfunction
Resource scarcity and climate stress lead populations to trade freedom for security
Technology provides permanent suppression capability preventing revolution or reform

global_scenarios.name: Digital Leapfrog Revolution
global_scenarios.description: Mobile technology, AI, fintech, and digital infrastructure enable developing nations to bypass traditional development stages. Remote work integration, blockchain-based property rights, and AI education systems provide unprecedented economic opportunities. Technology costs fall enabling universal digital access and participation in global economy.
key_drivers: Smartphone and internet penetration reaches 90%+ globally by 2035
AI-powered education systems provide personalized learning at under $10 per student annually
Digital payment systems and fintech reduce transaction costs by 80%+ in informal economies
Remote work opportunities grow to 15%+ of jobs in developing nations enabling global labor market access
Renewable energy costs fall enabling reliable electricity for under $5 per month per household

global_scenarios.name: Engineered Pandemic
global_scenarios.description: A deliberately designed or accidentally released engineered pathogen with high transmissibility and lethality overwhelms global health systems. Either through state bioweapon programs, AI-enabled terrorist design, or laboratory accident, multiple waves of highly lethal disease occur between 2030-2040, killing hundreds of millions before effective countermeasures deploy.
key_drivers: Synthetic biology capabilities advance enabling creation of highly lethal engineered pathogens
International biosecurity governance remains fragmented with inadequate surveillance
AI democratization enables malicious actors to design optimized bioweapons
Multiple simultaneous releases or mutations overwhelm healthcare infrastructure globally
Global coordination on pandemic response proves inadequate despite COVID-19 lessons

global_scenarios.name: Space Economy Expansion
global_scenarios.description: Dramatic reductions in launch costs and advances in orbital manufacturing, asteroid mining, or space-based solar power create thriving cislunar economy. Space-based production of semiconductors, pharmaceuticals, rare materials, or energy becomes cost-competitive with terrestrial alternatives by 2040s.
key_drivers: Launch costs drop below $100-300/kg by 2030-2035 through reusable systems
Zero-gravity manufacturing proves 10-100x more efficient for high-value specialized materials
Lunar or asteroid resource extraction achieves positive ROI by late 2030s
Space-based solar power or other energy systems achieve breakthrough economics
AI and robotics enable autonomous construction and operation of massive orbital facilities
