conditionals.reasoning: AI-driven productivity gains across all sectors would dramatically boost GDP growth. Successful workforce transitions and breakthrough scientific discoveries compound over 25+ years. Historical baseline US GDP ~$28T in 2024, this represents ~2.9% annual real growth through 2050.

Cascading climate failures between 2032-2045 would severely damage productive capacity. Crop failures, mass displacement, and resource conflicts devastate economic output. This represents negative to minimal real growth, with GDP potentially contracting from climate shocks.

Reduced trade flows, duplicated supply chains, limited technology transfer, and increased defense spending reduce efficiency gains. Fragmentation creates friction costs and reduces productivity growth to ~0.6% annually, well below historical trends.

Extended healthy working years (10-25 years), elimination of genetic diseases, and agricultural productivity surges significantly expand labor force and output. Healthcare cost reductions free resources for productive investment, supporting ~2.6% annual growth.

Japan-style lost decades at global scale with aging demographics, declining productivity, high debt, and political gridlock. Growth barely exceeds population growth at ~0.8% annually. Structural problems persist unaddressed for decades.

Massive coordinated investment creates new industrial revolution. Complete grid transformation, green technology exports, and avoided climate damages enable strong growth. Represents ~2.5% annual real growth with climate stabilization benefits.

Major armed conflict between nuclear powers with millions of casualties, infrastructure destruction, and economic disruption. Possibility of limited nuclear use or cyber-physical attacks devastates productive capacity. Recovery trajectory highly uncertain.

Engineered pathogen killing hundreds of millions between 2030-2040 decimates workforce and disrupts economic activity for extended period. Healthcare system collapse and social breakdown reduce long-term productive capacity significantly.

Extreme wealth concentration affects distribution but not necessarily aggregate GDP. Technology conglomerates capturing value may still drive overall growth through innovation, though consumption patterns shift. Moderate growth of ~1.6% annually with distributional concerns.

Despite periodic shocks, international cooperation and technological progress maintain development trajectory. Incremental improvements enable continued growth around ~1.7% annually—below historical US trends but avoiding catastrophic outcomes.

Rapid job elimination faster than creation reduces labor income and consumption. UBI/safety nets prevent collapse but growing non-employed population limits productivity gains. Growth slows to ~0.9% annually as traditional development pathways become obsolete.

US benefits from global market expansion as developing nations bypass traditional stages. Technology cost reductions and universal digital access create larger markets for US technology/services. Remote work integration expands talent pools, supporting ~2.3% annual growth.

Thriving cislunar economy by 2040s with cost-competitive space-based production adds entirely new economic sector. Semiconductor, pharmaceutical, and rare material production in orbit plus space-based solar power creates new growth engine, supporting ~2.7% annual growth.

Spread of digital totalitarianism creates less favorable global environment for US economic model. Reduced international cooperation, technology balkanization, and authoritarian competition limit US growth to ~1.0% annually as liberal democratic advantages erode.

Maintained strategic stability prevents catastrophic conflict but doesn't drive exceptional growth. Arms control renewal and limited proliferation create stable baseline environment. Represents moderate ~1.8% annual growth—continuation of recent trends without major disruptions.

AI-driven productivity gains across all sectors create unprecedented economic growth. Assuming 2024 GDP ~$105T and AI enabling 4.5-5.5% annual growth through workforce augmentation, new industries, and scientific breakthroughs.

Cascading climate failures destroy agricultural productivity, displace populations, and trigger resource conflicts. Multiple tipping points cause negative growth periods. Represents severe contraction from baseline trajectory.

Trade fragmentation, supply chain duplication, reduced technology transfer, and increased defense spending significantly reduce growth. Economic inefficiencies from competing standards and reduced globalization.

Extended healthy working years, elimination of major diseases, and agricultural productivity gains drive sustained growth. 10-25 year working life extensions plus AI-drug discovery create compounding benefits.
Global version of Japan's lost decades: aging demographics, productivity stagnation, high debt, policy gridlock. Growth averages 0.8-1.2% annually, well below historical norms.

Massive clean energy investment creates new industrial revolution. Cost reductions enable complete energy transformation, green tech exports boom, and climate damage costs stabilize through successful mitigation.

Major power conflict with millions of casualties, infrastructure destruction, and potential limited nuclear use devastates global economy. Supply chains collapse, trade halts, reconstruction dominates for decades.

Engineered pathogen killing hundreds of millions between 2030-2040 causes prolonged economic depression. Labor force decimation, healthcare system collapse, and sustained disruption to production and consumption.

Extreme inequality affects consumption patterns and investment but doesn't fundamentally change aggregate GDP growth trajectory. Wealth concentration is distributive issue more than total output determinant.

Baseline scenario with periodic shocks but continued incremental progress. Assumes ~2.5-3% annual growth from 2024 base of ~$105T, reflecting historical trends with moderate technological advancement and climate adaptation.

Rapid job displacement without replacement reduces consumption and creates social instability. However, automation still produces output; UBI/safety nets maintain some demand. Growth slows but remains positive.

Developing nations bypass traditional development stages through mobile tech, AI, and digital infrastructure. Dramatic reduction in global inequality as billions access digital economy, remote work, and AI education.

Cislunar economy becomes significant contributor by 2040s. Space-based manufacturing, asteroid mining, and orbital solar power create new high-value industries, though remain smaller fraction of total economy.

AI surveillance enables stable authoritarianism that suppresses innovation and entrepreneurship. While demonstrating some economic performance, central control limits creative destruction and productivity growth typical of market economies.

Nuclear deterrence holding is baseline assumption for non-catastrophic scenarios. Prevents worst outcomes but doesn't independently drive growth. Represents continuation of post-WWII stability enabling normal economic development.

AI-driven productivity and medical breakthroughs extend lifespans and improve healthcare, reducing mortality rates. Better resource management supports larger populations. Higher fertility in prosperous conditions.

Cascading climate failures cause mass mortality through crop failures, disease, displacement, and resource conflicts. Synchronized catastrophes between 2032-2045 significantly reduce population growth and increase death rates.

Fragmentation reduces cooperation on health, trade disruptions lower living standards, increased defense spending diverts resources from healthcare and development. Regional conflicts increase mortality.

Longevity treatments extending healthy years by 10-25 years dramatically reduce mortality rates. CRISPR eliminates genetic diseases, AI drug discovery cures previously fatal conditions. Agricultural advances support larger populations.

Prolonged low growth, aging demographics, and unaddressed structural problems reduce healthcare investment and living standards. Lower fertility in stagnant economies. Slower progress on mortality reduction.

Successful climate mitigation prevents catastrophic losses but doesn't dramatically change demographic fundamentals. Stabilized climate damage enables steady progress. Near baseline trajectory with moderate upside.

Major conflict between nuclear powers with millions of casualties, potential limited nuclear use, infrastructure destruction. Cascading economic collapse and societal breakdown create sustained elevated mortality and reduced fertility.

Engineered pathogen with high lethality kills hundreds of millions in multiple waves 2030-2040. Most severe demographic impact scenario. Societal disruption reduces fertility while mortality spikes dramatically.

Extreme inequality concentrates healthcare access among elites. Poor majority experiences reduced living standards and healthcare quality. Social instability and reduced investment in public health lower population growth.

Baseline scenario with manageable shocks and incremental improvements. UN medium variant projects around 9.7B. Continued healthcare progress balanced against aging demographics and moderate challenges.

Mass unemployment and social disruption reduce living standards for large populations. Economic insecurity lowers fertility rates. While UBI may provide subsistence, reduced optimism and opportunity decrease population growth.

Developing nations bypass traditional development constraints, accelerating economic growth and healthcare access. Universal digital participation improves education and health outcomes. Reduced infant mortality and moderate fertility increases.

Space economy creates new industries but minimal direct demographic impact by 2050. Wealth generation may marginally improve conditions but space population remains negligible. Near baseline trajectory.

AI surveillance enables stable authoritarian control but often correlates with lower living standards, reduced healthcare quality, and fertility suppression. Oppressive systems may demonstrate economic performance but limit human flourishing.

Deterrence holding prevents catastrophic nuclear conflict but doesn't fundamentally change demographic trajectories. Represents successful avoidance of worst-case scenario, allowing baseline trends to continue.

AI-driven productivity gains and successful workforce transitions create unprecedented economic growth and job creation. New industries and AI-augmented capabilities drive wealth generation that reaches lower-income populations. Breakthrough scientific progress reduces costs of essentials.

Cascading climate failures destroy agricultural systems and displace hundreds of millions. Synchronized crop failures, water scarcity, and resource conflicts push vast populations back into extreme poverty. Adaptation efforts prove insufficient as impacts accelerate.

Economic fragmentation reduces trade flows and technology transfer, limiting development pathways for poor nations. Supply chain duplication increases costs. Reduced international cooperation undermines poverty reduction efforts. Competing spheres create economic inefficiencies.

Extended healthy working years and elimination of genetic diseases dramatically boost productivity. Agricultural breakthroughs through synthetic biology massively reduce food costs. AI-accelerated treatments cure diseases that trap populations in poverty cycles.

Global low-growth environment limits job creation and wage growth. High debt burdens prevent poverty reduction investments. Political gridlock blocks reforms. Declining productivity growth reduces resources available for development programs and safety nets.

Massive clean energy investment creates jobs and new industries. Breakthrough cost reductions in renewables lower energy costs for poor populations. Successful climate mitigation prevents catastrophic disruptions. Green technology exports drive growth in developing nations.

Major armed conflict between nuclear powers causes millions of casualties and widespread economic collapse. Infrastructure destruction, supply chain disruption, and resource scarcity push massive populations into extreme poverty. Recovery takes decades.

Engineered pathogen killing hundreds of millions devastates economic systems and labor forces. Healthcare system collapse, orphaning of children, and destruction of human capital create poverty traps. Multiple waves between 2030-2040 prevent recovery.

Extreme wealth concentration with returns to capital dominating returns to labor leaves lower-income populations behind. Winner-take-all dynamics and failed redistribution mechanisms prevent poverty reduction. Technology gains accrue primarily to capital owners and elite workers.

Baseline scenario where continued development and international cooperation enable poverty reduction despite periodic setbacks. Incremental improvements in governance, healthcare, and technology maintain historical poverty reduction trends with some disruptions.

Rapid job elimination faster than creation eliminates traditional development pathways, especially in manufacturing and services. Developing nations lose labor-intensive industrialization routes. Safety nets may be insufficient in low-income countries without fiscal capacity.

Mobile technology and AI enable developing nations to bypass traditional stages. Universal digital access provides unprecedented economic opportunities through remote work, fintech, and AI education. Falling technology costs democratize participation in global economy.

Thriving space economy creates new high-value industries and dramatically reduces costs of materials, semiconductors, and potentially energy. Economic growth and technological spillovers benefit terrestrial economy. New employment sectors emerge with growing opportunities.

AI-enabled authoritarian systems may demonstrate sustained economic performance while suppressing dissent. Stable governance could enable development programs, but lack of political freedom and innovation constraints create uncertain poverty outcomes roughly similar to mixed historical authoritarian records.

Maintenance of nuclear deterrence prevents catastrophic great power war but doesn't fundamentally change economic development trajectories. Arms control and stability enable continued international cooperation similar to baseline progress scenario.

AI-driven prosperity enhances disaster prediction, medical response capabilities, and resource management, reducing catastrophic risk probabilities. However, some AI-related catastrophic risks remain possible.

Cascading climate failures triggering synchronized crop failures, mass displacement, and resource conflicts create conditions where famine, disease, and conflict could combine to reach 10% mortality threshold through compounding effects.

Fragmentation increases conflict risk, reduces cooperative pandemic response, and weakens global coordination on existential threats. Arms races and nationalist tensions elevate tail risks substantially.

Enhanced medical capabilities reduce natural pandemic severity, but widespread biotech access also increases dual-use risks. Greater lab accidents possible but better treatments available. Effects roughly balance to baseline levels.

Stagnation reduces resources for catastrophe prevention but also limits technological risks and conflict capabilities. Social stress increases but without clear pathway to 10% mortality threshold. Near baseline risk.

Successful climate mitigation eliminates the highest-probability catastrophic scenario (climate cascade). Coordinated international investment demonstrates functional global governance, reducing other catastrophic risks.

By definition involves major conflict between nuclear powers with potential limited nuclear use, infrastructure collapse, and cascading failures. Direct combat casualties plus famine and disease from societal breakdown could reach threshold.

Scenario explicitly describes engineered pathogen killing hundreds of millions before countermeasures. High transmissibility and lethality with multiple waves directly targets the 10% mortality threshold by design.

Extreme inequality creates social instability but doesn't directly produce catastrophic mortality events. Weakened social cohesion slightly elevates risk of conflict or pandemic response failure but remains near baseline.

By definition describes successful navigation of shocks with functional cooperation and adequate response capabilities. Periodic moderate crises occur but catastrophic outcomes are specifically prevented through resilience.

Labor displacement creates social stress and political instability but safety nets prevent mass starvation. No clear mechanism to 10% mortality without additional catastrophic triggers. Near baseline risk.

Reduced global inequality, expanded opportunity, and improved connectivity strengthen social cohesion and crisis response capabilities. Technology diffusion enables better early warning systems and coordination.

Space economy has minimal direct impact on terrestrial catastrophe probability. Slightly reduces resource competition pressures but doesn't fundamentally alter major risk pathways. Near baseline risk.

AI surveillance enables stable authoritarian control, potentially reducing some conflict risks through effective suppression. However, reduced transparency may hide emerging threats. Roughly neutral effect on catastrophic mortality.

Sustained nuclear deterrence and improved safeguards eliminate the highest single-event catastrophic risk. Effective arms control demonstrates functional great power coordination, reducing overall catastrophic risk substantially.

Rapid AI advancement increases capability risks. While prosperity suggests good governance, the speed of development creates alignment challenges and potential for accidents or misuse during the transition period.

Climate pressures might accelerate AI deployment for solutions, but AI catastrophe risk is more orthogonal to climate dynamics. Resource scarcity could reduce AI investment, roughly balancing acceleration effects.

Fragmentation creates race dynamics where multiple powers rush AI development without coordination. Reduced information sharing, duplicated safety research, and competitive pressures increase accident probability and adversarial deployment risks.
Biotech advances are largely independent of AI catastrophe risk. Some correlation exists through general technological capacity, but biotech focus doesn't directly affect AI safety trajectories.

Stagnation slows AI development timelines significantly. Reduced investment, slower hardware progress, and limited deployment mean transformative AI arrives later or not at all by 2050, substantially reducing catastrophe probability.

Coordinated global action on climate demonstrates governance capacity and international cooperation. This institutional strength likely transfers to AI governance, reducing catastrophic risk through better safety frameworks and coordination.

Major conflict dramatically increases AI catastrophe risk through weaponized AI systems, rushed deployment without safety measures, adversarial AI development, and breakdown of coordination mechanisms. Conflict creates conditions for both accidental and intentional AI catastrophes.

Pandemic may accelerate AI for biodefense but also disrupts research institutions. Effects are mixed - crisis might increase AI deployment speed but also reduces overall technological capacity through population and economic impacts.

Concentrated AI development in few tech oligopolies reduces diversity of safety approaches and oversight. Winner-take-all dynamics create pressure for rapid deployment. Reduced regulatory effectiveness increases risks from profit-maximizing AI deployment.

This scenario explicitly features successful management of technological risks including AI. International cooperation, effective governance, and incremental progress suggest safety-conscious AI development with strong coordination mechanisms.

Rapid automation implies fast AI capability growth outpacing social adaptation. Job displacement demonstrates AI systems operating beyond human control in economic domain, suggesting insufficient safety measures and alignment failures that could extend to catastrophic domains.

Widespread digital access distributes AI development more broadly but doesn't inherently change catastrophe risk trajectory. More actors might increase risk slightly, but technology democratization is roughly neutral on existential safety questions.

Space focus redirects resources and talent away from pure AI development. Demonstrates successful management of complex technological transitions. Space industry requires long-term thinking and safety culture that likely benefits AI governance.

AI-enabled authoritarianism indicates widespread deployment of powerful AI control systems. Optimizing for social control rather than safety, reduced transparency, and concentration of AI power in state actors increases both misuse and accident risks substantially.

Maintained nuclear stability demonstrates successful management of existential risks through international cooperation and institutional safeguards. This governance capacity and caution around catastrophic technologies likely extends to AI safety, reducing catastrophe probability.

AI-driven prosperity enhances early warning systems, crisis management, and diplomatic coordination. Economic interdependence and scientific cooperation reduce conflict incentives. However, AI could also accelerate arms races.

Cascading resource failures, mass displacement, and synchronized crop failures create extreme geopolitical stress. Water and food conflicts could escalate to nuclear exchange, especially in South Asia or Middle East regions with nuclear arsenals.

Competing spheres of influence, reduced dialogue channels, and arms race dynamics substantially increase nuclear risk. Decoupling reduces stabilizing economic interdependence while nationalist tensions rise.

Extended healthy lifespans and improved health reduce resource scarcity pressures. Leaders making more rational long-term decisions. However, biotech doesn't directly address nuclear command/control issues.

Prolonged low growth creates domestic political instability, populist nationalism, and scapegoating dynamics. Resource competition intensifies while cooperative frameworks weaken, though outright conflict still faces high barriers.

Successful climate mitigation reduces resource conflict drivers. International cooperation on climate builds diplomatic channels and trust. Energy independence from renewables reduces geopolitical flashpoints over fossil fuels.

By definition involves major armed conflict between nuclear powers with explicit possibility of limited nuclear use. Escalation dynamics, fog of war, and AI-accelerated weapons create high risk of reaching 10% population threshold.

Massive death toll and societal breakdown create instability and potential for nuclear command/control failures. Blame attribution could trigger retaliation. However, pandemic itself may incapacitate war-making capacity.

Extreme inequality fuels domestic instability, revolutionary movements, and regime insecurity. Oligarchic capture of nuclear states could lead to reckless decisions, though concentrated wealth also fears asset destruction.

Strong international cooperation and effective crisis management reduce nuclear risks despite periodic shocks. Incremental improvements in safeguards, arms control, and conflict resolution mechanisms maintain stability.

Mass unemployment creates severe domestic instability, extremist movements, and regime insecurity. Leaders may pursue aggressive foreign policies to distract from domestic failures. Social breakdown weakens nuclear security.

Neutral overall - digital advancement reduces some conflict drivers through opportunity but doesn't fundamentally alter nuclear deterrence dynamics. Developing world integration has mixed effects on stability.

Resource abundance from space reduces scarcity-driven conflicts. Economic expansion into cislunar space provides growth outlet reducing zero-sum Earth-based competition. Technological advancement improves crisis management.

Neutral to slightly elevated - stable authoritarian control reduces revolutionary instability but increases regime survival desperation. Digital totalitarianism could improve nuclear security or create brittle command structures vulnerable to crisis.
By definition, deterrence holds and safeguards improve. Arms control frameworks, limited proliferation, and improved accident prevention substantially reduce nuclear catastrophe risk through 2050.

AI-driven prosperity enhances biosurveillance, pathogen detection, and rapid countermeasure development. Stronger global cooperation and scientific capabilities reduce bioweapon development incentives and improve defensive capabilities.

Resource scarcity, mass displacement, and state collapse create conditions for desperate actors to deploy bioweapons. Weakened international institutions reduce oversight of bioweapon programs while public health systems deteriorate.

Competing power blocs pursue covert bioweapon programs with reduced international transparency. Arms control frameworks weaken and asymmetric warfare incentives increase. Technology transfer restrictions complicate but don't prevent bioweapon development.

Widespread access to advanced biotechnology dramatically lowers barriers to engineering deadly pathogens. Even with defensive improvements, the dual-use nature of biotech and proliferation of capabilities to non-state actors substantially increases catastrophic bioweapon risk.

Prolonged low growth constrains bioweapon program funding and reduces geopolitical tensions somewhat, but also limits investment in biosecurity infrastructure. Overall effect roughly neutral as competing factors balance.

Successful climate mitigation reduces resource conflicts and state failures that could motivate bioweapon use. Enhanced international cooperation and institutional strength improve biosecurity governance and monitoring capabilities.

Major power conflict creates strong incentives for asymmetric warfare including bioweapon deployment. Conventional war breakdown of norms, desperation dynamics, and potential for escalation to biological warfare substantially increase catastrophic bioweapon use probability.

This scenario directly describes a catastrophic bioweapon event occurring. An engineered pandemic killing hundreds of millions between 2030-2040 would almost certainly exceed the 10% global population threshold for catastrophe definition.

Extreme inequality and social instability increase terrorism risk and reduce state capacity for biosecurity in many regions. Concentration of biotech capabilities in oligarchic structures may reduce oversight while grievances against techno-elite create bioweapon attack motivations.

Effective international cooperation and technological progress strengthen biosecurity frameworks, pathogen surveillance, and rapid response capabilities. Periodic shocks are managed without catastrophic escalation, keeping bioweapon risks at relatively low baseline levels.

Mass unemployment creates social instability but doesn't directly increase bioweapon capabilities or strong motivations for catastrophic attacks. Safety nets may reduce grievance-driven terrorism. Overall effect relatively neutral with slight upward pressure from instability.

Inclusive economic growth and integration into global systems reduces motivations for catastrophic attacks. Digital infrastructure enables better disease surveillance and international cooperation on biosecurity. Reduced development grievances lower terrorism risks.

Space economy growth has limited direct effect on bioweapon risks. Slight positive effect from technology spillovers to biosurveillance and economic prosperity roughly balanced by potential access to space-based biological research and new asymmetric warfare vectors.

AI-enabled authoritarian states may pursue covert bioweapon programs with reduced transparency and accountability. Surveillance capabilities prevent some non-state attacks but state-level programs face fewer constraints. Competition between authoritarian and democratic blocs increases security dilemma dynamics.

Maintained nuclear deterrence and arms control frameworks demonstrate successful international security cooperation that extends to biological weapons treaties. Improved safeguards and crisis management capabilities reduce probability of desperate bioweapon deployment scenarios.

AI-driven prosperity improves safety systems, disaster prediction, infrastructure resilience, and resource management. Enhanced monitoring and coordination reduce catastrophic risks from industrial accidents, environmental disasters, and infrastructure failures.

Cascading climate failures could trigger synchronized global crop failures, water crises, and mass displacement leading to societal collapse in multiple regions simultaneously. Resource conflicts, famine, and disease in destabilized areas could reach catastrophic scale.

Fragmentation weakens global coordination on safety standards, disaster response, and risk management. Reduced cooperation on climate adaptation, industrial safety protocols, and infrastructure investment increases vulnerability to cascading failures.

Extended healthy lifespans and disease elimination reduce population vulnerability. Enhanced agricultural productivity through synthetic biology provides buffer against food system shocks. Better health resilience reduces catastrophic mortality from non-bioweapon causes.

Stagnation maintains status quo risk levels. Limited resources for infrastructure upgrades or climate adaptation, but also slower industrial expansion that might create new risks. Baseline scenario with modest upward drift from accumulating deferred maintenance.

Successful climate mitigation reduces risk of climate-driven catastrophes. Investment in resilient infrastructure, circular economy, and adaptation measures substantially lowers vulnerability to environmental and resource-based catastrophic failures.

Major conventional war between great powers could involve cyber-physical attacks on critical infrastructure (dams, chemical plants, power grids), resource deprivation, and cascading industrial accidents. Mass displacement and infrastructure destruction could reach catastrophic mortality thresholds.

This scenario specifically covers bioweapon/pandemic, which is excluded from the question. However, societal disruption from engineered pandemic could indirectly enable other catastrophes through infrastructure neglect, food system breakdown, or secondary conflicts over scarce resources.

Extreme inequality and oligarchic control could lead to underinvestment in public infrastructure safety, climate adaptation, and social stability. Mass discontent, breakdown of social cohesion, and neglect of critical systems increases catastrophic failure risks.

By definition, this scenario involves successful management of various risks through cooperation and adaptation. Improved governance, healthcare, and resilience measures specifically prevent catastrophic outcomes despite periodic shocks.

Mass unemployment without adequate safety nets could trigger social breakdown, riots, and state failures in multiple countries. Cascading effects of political instability, infrastructure neglect, and potential revolutionary violence could reach catastrophic scale.

Improved global connectivity, economic opportunity, and technology access reduces desperation-driven conflicts and state failures. Better distributed prosperity and development pathways lower risks of catastrophic social breakdown and resource wars.

Space economy expansion provides resource abundance, reduces terrestrial resource competition, and creates economic growth that funds safety investments. Reduced pressure on Earth's resources lowers catastrophic conflict and environmental collapse risks.

AI surveillance enables stable authoritarianism that could either prevent or enable catastrophes. Tighter control might prevent some chaotic failures but authoritarian miscalculation, repression-driven unrest, or system brittleness could trigger catastrophic collapse. Near baseline risk.

Nuclear deterrence holding removes one major catastrophic risk pathway. Stable great power relations enable better cooperation on other global challenges including climate, industrial safety, and disaster response, reducing non-nuclear catastrophic risks.

AI-driven advances in early warning systems, asteroid detection/deflection, volcanic monitoring, and disaster response significantly reduce vulnerability to natural catastrophes. Enhanced predictive capabilities and coordinated global response mechanisms lower risk.

While climate change is anthropogenic, this scenario doesn't directly affect non-anthropogenic risks like asteroid impacts, supervolcanic eruptions, or gamma-ray bursts. The catastrophe must be from non-human sources, so climate impacts don't count here.

Fragmentation may reduce coordinated response to natural threats but doesn't fundamentally change the likelihood of asteroids, supervolcanoes, or other non-anthropogenic events occurring. Baseline risk persists.

Advanced biotechnology enables better detection and response to natural pandemic threats (though engineered pandemics are anthropogenic). Longevity treatments and health advances don't prevent natural catastrophes but improve resilience and recovery capacity.

Economic conditions don't significantly affect the occurrence rate of asteroid impacts, supervolcanic eruptions, or other natural catastrophic events. These remain independent of human economic activity.

Green transition addresses anthropogenic climate change but doesn't materially affect non-anthropogenic catastrophe risks. Natural disasters like asteroid impacts or supervolcanic eruptions remain unchanged.

Great power conflict is itself anthropogenic. While it might distract from natural threat monitoring, the question specifically asks about non-anthropogenic sources, which remain at baseline probability.

Engineered pandemics are anthropogenic by definition. This scenario doesn't affect the likelihood of naturally occurring catastrophes from geological or astronomical sources that would cause 10%+ population death.
Wealth distribution patterns don't significantly influence the probability of non-anthropogenic natural catastrophes like asteroid impacts or supervolcanic eruptions occurring by 2050.

This scenario represents moderate baseline conditions. Non-anthropogenic catastrophe risks (asteroids, supervolcanoes) remain at their natural baseline probability, unaffected by human progress levels.

Labor market disruptions don't materially affect the occurrence probability of natural catastrophes from non-human sources. Asteroid impacts and geological events remain independent of employment patterns.
Digital development in emerging economies doesn't significantly alter the probability of non-anthropogenic natural catastrophes. These events occur independently of technological diffusion patterns.

Extensive space activity increases human exposure to space-based natural hazards (solar storms, micro-meteorites affecting orbital infrastructure, cosmic radiation). While asteroid detection improves, the expanded human presence in space creates new vulnerabilities to non-anthropogenic cosmic threats.

Governance systems don't fundamentally change the occurrence rate of natural catastrophes from non-anthropogenic sources. Asteroids, supervolcanoes, and other geological/astronomical events remain independent of political systems.

Nuclear deterrence addresses anthropogenic conflict risks but doesn't affect non-anthropogenic natural catastrophe probability. Natural disasters from geological or astronomical sources occur independently of nuclear policy.

AI-driven medical breakthroughs, drug discovery acceleration, and improved healthcare delivery systems substantially extend life expectancy beyond baseline trends. Productivity gains enable better resource allocation to health.

Cascading climate failures cause malnutrition, disease vector expansion, heat mortality, conflict, and mass displacement. Synchronized crop failures and water scarcity severely impact global health outcomes.

Reduced international cooperation limits pandemic response, technology transfer, and medical research collaboration. Trade disruptions affect access to medicines and healthcare resources, though developed regions maintain progress.

Anti-aging treatments, CRISPR gene therapies, and AI-accelerated drug discovery directly target age-related diseases and extend healthy lifespan. Elimination of genetic diseases and previously incurable conditions dramatically improves longevity.

Low growth constrains healthcare investment and innovation. Aging demographics strain systems while limited fiscal space prevents expansion. Progress continues but slower than potential, with reduced R&D spending.

Successful climate mitigation stabilizes environmental health determinants. Reduced air pollution from clean energy dramatically improves respiratory and cardiovascular health. Climate damage costs remain manageable.

Major conflict between nuclear powers causes millions of direct casualties, infrastructure destruction, healthcare system collapse, disease outbreaks, and long-term radiation or environmental contamination effects.

Engineered pathogen kills hundreds of millions across multiple waves. Even after countermeasures deploy, population structure is altered and healthcare systems remain disrupted for years, substantially reducing global life expectancy.

Extreme inequality reduces access to healthcare for large populations despite technological advances. Wealth concentration limits diffusion of medical innovations, creating two-tier health outcomes with large populations lacking access.

Baseline scenario with continued incremental medical progress, gradual improvements in healthcare access, and manageable climate/conflict impacts. WHO trends suggest steady gains from current ~73 years, reaching mid-70s by 2050.

Mass unemployment creates social stress, mental health crises, and reduced access to healthcare for displaced workers. However, UBI or safety nets partially mitigate worst outcomes. Healthcare automation may improve efficiency.

Developing nations rapidly improve healthcare access through telemedicine, AI diagnostics, and mobile health platforms. Bypassing traditional infrastructure enables faster convergence toward developed-world health outcomes.

Space economy primarily affects industrial production rather than direct health outcomes. Some pharmaceutical production in space and economic growth benefits health marginally, but impact on life expectancy is limited.

AI surveillance enables stable authoritarian governance but often prioritizes control over citizen welfare. Reduced freedom correlates with health impacts through stress, suppressed information, and resource allocation favoring regime security over healthcare.

Nuclear deterrence holding prevents catastrophic conflict but doesn't directly improve health outcomes. This represents continuation of current strategic stability with baseline medical and technological progress.

AI-driven prosperity creates economic abundance and educational opportunities that support democratic institutions. Prosperity correlates historically with democratization, though AI surveillance risks exist.

Cascading climate failures trigger resource conflicts, mass migrations, and state failures. Authoritarian emergency powers become normalized. Democratic institutions collapse under crisis pressure and refugee flows destabilize remaining democracies.

Competing spheres of influence reduce democratic pressure on authoritarian regimes. Fragmentation enables alternative governance models to consolidate without Western integration incentives. Cold War-style ideological competition favors stability over liberalization.

Health improvements and extended working years increase human capital but don't directly affect governance structures. Could enable both more capable democratic participation and longer-lived autocratic leaders. Net effect relatively neutral.

Prolonged stagnation erodes democratic legitimacy as governments fail to deliver prosperity. Populist movements and authoritarian alternatives gain appeal. Youth unemployment and economic frustration fuel political instability and democratic backsliding.

Coordinated climate action requires international cooperation and civil society engagement, strengthening democratic norms. Green economy creates new industries and reduces resource conflicts. Successful mitigation demonstrates democratic problem-solving capacity.

Major war triggers emergency powers, surveillance expansion, and authoritarian measures in democracies. Post-conflict reconstruction often favors strongman rule. Societal breakdown and millions of casualties destroy institutional capacity. Democratic norms collapse under existential threat.

Engineered pandemic killing hundreds of millions creates permanent emergency governance. Biosecurity surveillance becomes ubiquitous. Authoritarian systems demonstrate crisis management advantages. Democratic deliberation seen as luxury; expedient control measures persist.

Extreme inequality undermines democratic equality principles. Oligarchic capture of institutions and media reduces meaningful political competition. Economic power translates to political control. Growing underclass becomes disillusioned with democratic processes that fail to address concentration.

Baseline scenario with mixed trends continuing. Democratic backsliding in some regions offset by improvements in others. Technology enables both democratic participation and authoritarian control. Incremental progress maintains rough stability around current 33% free democracy level.

Mass unemployment creates social instability and political extremism. Unemployed populations vulnerable to populist authoritarians promising order. Democratic institutions struggle to manage technological displacement. UBI implementation varies, with authoritarian systems potentially more decisive.

Digital infrastructure empowers civil society, enables transparent governance, and facilitates democratic participation in developing nations. Blockchain property rights reduce corruption. Information access undermines authoritarian control. Developing world democratization increases global proportion substantially.

Space economy creates new wealth and opportunities but doesn't fundamentally alter terrestrial governance dynamics. Benefits likely concentrated in already-developed nations. Marginal positive effect through prosperity but not transformative for democratic institutions.

AI surveillance makes authoritarian systems stable and difficult to overthrow. Digital totalitarianism proves economically viable, removing development-democracy correlation. Social control systems spread globally. Democratic movements face unprecedented suppression capabilities. Authoritarian model becomes attractive alternative.

Nuclear stability prevents catastrophic conflicts but doesn't directly drive democratization or authoritarianism. Maintains status quo security environment. Arms control cooperation marginally positive but insufficient to significantly shift governance trends. Near-neutral baseline effect.

AI-driven prosperity reduces conflict through economic growth, improved resource allocation, and enhanced diplomatic tools. Better early warning systems and conflict prevention mechanisms reduce battle deaths substantially below baseline.

Cascading climate failures trigger massive resource wars, displacement conflicts, and state collapse scenarios. Food and water scarcity drive armed conflicts across vulnerable regions, multiplying battle deaths significantly.

Competing spheres of influence increase proxy wars, regional conflicts, and arms races. Reduced cooperation and higher defense spending create multiple flashpoints, substantially elevating conflict deaths above baseline.

Health improvements and extended lifespans reduce demographic pressures and youth bulges traditionally associated with conflict. Enhanced medical capabilities reduce battle-related mortality rates, lowering overall deaths.

Prolonged low growth creates frustration and political instability but lacks the acute shocks that trigger major wars. Regional conflicts persist at historically moderate levels without dramatic escalation.

Successful climate mitigation reduces resource scarcity conflicts. International cooperation on green technology and shared challenges builds diplomatic frameworks that prevent escalation of disputes.

Major great power war with potential nuclear use and AI-accelerated weapons produces casualties in the millions to tens of millions. Direct conflict plus proxy wars and regional spillovers create unprecedented battle deaths.

Engineered pandemic causes state collapse, resource conflicts, and breakdown of order in affected regions. Military conflicts over medical resources, quarantine enforcement, and attribution of bioweapon origin multiply battle deaths substantially.

Extreme inequality fuels social instability, insurgencies, and revolutionary movements. Resource concentration creates grievances that manifest in armed conflicts, particularly in regions with weak governance.

Baseline scenario with periodic regional conflicts and manageable setbacks. International cooperation prevents catastrophic escalation while localized wars continue at historically moderate rates similar to 2010-2020 trends.

Mass unemployment and loss of traditional development pathways destabilize developing nations. Displaced populations and economic desperation fuel insurgencies, civil wars, and state fragility, significantly increasing battle deaths.

Economic opportunities through digital access reduce grievances in developing nations. Improved governance through technology and global economic integration decrease conflict drivers, lowering battle deaths.

New economic frontiers and resource access reduce terrestrial competition. Space economy creates prosperity and cooperation frameworks that minimize Earth-based conflicts, though some space-related disputes possible.

AI surveillance enables stable authoritarian control, reducing civil wars and insurgencies within such states. However, inter-state conflicts and resistance movements in transition zones maintain moderate conflict levels.

Strong deterrence prevents major power wars and limits escalation of regional conflicts. Arms control and improved safeguards keep conflicts conventional and localized, substantially reducing battle death potential.

AI productivity gains create new wealth but also new opportunities. Winner-take-all dynamics partially offset by new industries and human-AI collaboration enabling broader participation. Net effect roughly neutral relative to baseline trends.

Cascading failures destroy middle-class wealth through property losses, displacement, and economic disruption while ultra-wealthy preserve assets through geographic diversification, climate-resilient investments, and resource control during scarcity.

Reduced trade and economic integration favor incumbent capital holders and defense contractors. Fragmented markets create monopolistic opportunities in regional spheres. Middle-class wealth eroded by reduced growth and opportunity.

Longevity treatments and health advances initially favor wealthy but eventually democratize. Extended working years benefit capital owners but also preserve human capital. Productivity gains widely distributed through healthcare improvements.

Low growth environment with limited policy tools favors existing capital holders. Asset price inflation from zero rates benefits wealthy disproportionately. Lack of economic dynamism prevents wealth creation for middle class while top tier preserves position.

Massive coordinated investment creates new industries and broad employment opportunities. Democratized energy access reduces wealth extraction opportunities. Strong growth and policy coordination enables progressive redistribution and limits concentration.

Major warfare destroys middle-class wealth through infrastructure damage, displacement, and economic collapse while ultra-wealthy preserve assets offshore and profit from defense production, reconstruction contracts, and resource scarcity during conflict.

Engineered pandemic kills hundreds of millions, disproportionately affecting working populations. Wealthy protect themselves through private healthcare, isolation, early access to treatments. Massive wealth transfer through inheritance, asset purchases during crisis, and economic concentration.

This scenario directly describes extreme wealth concentration through winner-take-all AI/automation dynamics and regulatory failure. Technology conglomerates and capital owners capture unprecedented value while labor returns collapse and redistribution mechanisms fail.

Incremental progress with manageable setbacks represents continuation of recent trends with modest concentration pressures from technology balanced by governance improvements and continued development creating middle-class wealth.

Mass labor displacement without job creation concentrates income with capital owners and AI system controllers. UBI may prevent destitution but creates dependency while wealth generation increasingly flows to small elite controlling automation infrastructure.

Technology democratization enables developing nations to participate in global economy, creating new wealth among previously excluded populations. Falling technology costs and universal access reduce barriers, enabling broad-based wealth creation that dilutes top concentration.

High capital requirements for space industry favor existing ultra-wealthy and major corporations. Early-mover advantages in asteroid mining and orbital manufacturing create monopolistic positions. Space resources controlled by small elite with access to launch capability and investment capital.

AI surveillance enables stable authoritarianism where ruling elites extract rents without accountability. Digital totalitarianism prevents wealth redistribution while technology-enabled control systems concentrate economic power with regime-connected oligarchs and party elites.

Stable deterrence prevents catastrophic wealth destruction from nuclear conflict but doesn't fundamentally alter wealth concentration dynamics. Security stability enables continued economic development with baseline technology and policy trends determining distribution.

AI augmentation extends working years and creates human-AI collaborative roles. Enhanced productivity and new industries increase labor demand while medical breakthroughs enable longer healthy working lives, pushing participation above historical trends.

Cascading climate failures cause mass displacement, resource conflicts, and economic disruption. Survival priorities and breakdown of institutions reduce formal labor force participation. Disease vectors and crop failures force population into subsistence activities outside measured workforce.

Trade fragmentation and defense spending shifts reduce economic efficiency. Duplicated supply chains and reduced technology transfer lower productivity growth. Economic inefficiency and potential regional conflicts modestly depress participation rates.

Anti-aging treatments extending healthy working years by 10-25 years dramatically increases labor force participation among older cohorts. Elimination of genetic diseases and treatments for chronic conditions enable more people to work productively into their 70s and 80s.

Prolonged low growth resembling Japan's lost decades. Discouraged workers exit labor force permanently. Low productivity growth and political gridlock prevent reforms that could boost participation. Demographics and structural problems create persistent slack.

Massive clean energy investment creates new industrial revolution with significant job creation in manufacturing, installation, and maintenance. Green technology sectors provide diverse employment opportunities. Economic growth from exports and innovation increases labor demand.

Major armed conflict with millions of casualties and widespread infrastructure destruction. Military mobilization removes workers, while physical and economic disruption prevents normal labor force participation. Societal breakdown and displacement create lasting impacts on work capacity.

Engineered pathogen killing hundreds of millions between 2030-2040 drastically reduces working-age population. Survivors face long-term health impacts reducing work capacity. Economic and institutional disruption creates lasting barriers to labor force reentry and measurement.

Extreme wealth concentration reduces labor's share of income. Winner-take-all dynamics and returns to capital dominating returns to labor discourage workforce participation. Growing rentier class and insufficient employment opportunities push people out of measured labor force.

Baseline scenario with incremental improvements balancing periodic shocks. Technological progress and healthcare advances modestly increase participation while aging demographics create downward pressure. Cooperation prevents catastrophic outcomes but change is gradual.

Rapid job elimination across transportation, manufacturing, retail, and administrative sectors. Job creation lags displacement significantly. Universal basic income or expanded safety nets support non-employed population who exit measured labor force as traditional work opportunities disappear.

While transformative for developing nations, direct impact on US labor force participation is limited. Remote work integration and digital access provide modest opportunities but don't fundamentally alter US demographic or economic participation trends compared to baseline.

Thriving cislunar economy creates new high-skill employment in manufacturing, mining, and energy production. Space-based industries generate terrestrial support jobs in engineering, logistics, and operations. Novel economic sector increases overall labor demand and participation.

While affecting governance and civil liberties, AI surveillance systems don't directly determine US labor force participation rates. Economic performance could vary but baseline participation trends remain primary driver. Indirect effects through political stability are ambiguous.

Strategic stability prevents catastrophic disruption but doesn't actively increase or decrease participation. Arms control and deterrence maintain status quo security environment. Labor force participation driven by other demographic and economic factors rather than nuclear dynamics.

AI-driven medical breakthroughs, improved diagnostics, and automated healthcare delivery dramatically reduce childhood mortality. AI augments disease surveillance and enables personalized treatments even in resource-constrained settings.

Cascading climate failures devastate food and water systems, expand disease vectors like malaria, cause mass displacement disrupting healthcare, and trigger conflicts that destroy medical infrastructure. Under-5 mortality reverses decades of progress.

Fragmentation reduces international health cooperation, duplicates vaccine development efforts, limits technology transfer to developing nations, and increases defense spending at expense of health systems. Trade barriers reduce access to medicines and equipment.

CRISPR eliminates genetic diseases, gene therapies cure previously fatal conditions, and AI-accelerated drug discovery creates treatments for childhood diseases. Synthetic biology enhances nutrition and agricultural productivity reduces malnutrition deaths.

Prolonged low growth limits public health investment, reduces resources for vaccination programs, weakens healthcare infrastructure expansion, and constrains international development aid. Progress stalls but doesn't reverse completely.

Successful climate mitigation prevents worst health impacts while clean energy reduces air pollution deaths. Coordinated investment strengthens public health systems. Climate damage costs stabilize enabling continued health improvements.

Major conflict destroys healthcare infrastructure, displaces populations, disrupts vaccination programs, causes famines, and potentially involves nuclear or biological weapons. Millions of direct casualties include many children, with long-term health system collapse.

Engineered pathogen with high lethality kills hundreds of millions including disproportionate child deaths. Multiple waves overwhelm health systems, disrupt supply chains, and create lasting economic damage that undermines healthcare capacity for decades.

Extreme inequality limits healthcare access for poor populations. Technology benefits accrue to wealthy regions while developing nations lack resources for health improvements. Insufficient redistribution prevents universal health coverage expansion.

Baseline scenario with continued incremental progress despite setbacks. International cooperation maintains vaccination programs, medical technology improves gradually, and adaptation manages climate pressures. Follows historical improvement trajectory with moderate challenges.

Mass unemployment reduces household incomes limiting healthcare access. Social safety nets strain under pressure. Economic disruption particularly impacts developing nations where labor-intensive development pathways close, slowing health system improvements.

Mobile health platforms, AI diagnostics, and telemedicine reach remote populations. Digital infrastructure enables vaccination tracking, remote consultation, and health education. Developing nations bypass traditional healthcare infrastructure limitations through technology.

Space economy has minimal direct impact on childhood mortality. Potential pharmaceutical manufacturing in space or economic spillovers provide modest benefits, but core determinants of child health remain terrestrial healthcare systems and living conditions.

AI surveillance enables efficient public health monitoring and compliance enforcement. Some regimes prioritize child health outcomes for legitimacy. However, oppression may limit healthcare innovation and international cooperation. Mixed effects approximate baseline progress.

Nuclear deterrence maintaining stability prevents catastrophic conflict scenarios but doesn't directly improve health outcomes. Represents continuation of current trends without major disruption, similar to resilient progress baseline.

AI-driven productivity gains significantly increase returns to capital relative to labor. While new jobs emerge, AI augmentation and automation shift income toward capital owners and high-skill AI developers, reducing labor's share of total income.

Climate catastrophe devastates capital stock through infrastructure destruction, agricultural failures, and stranded assets. Labor becomes relatively more important for basic survival activities, reconstruction, and adaptation efforts, increasing labor's share as physical capital is destroyed.

Trade fragmentation reduces capital efficiency through duplicated supply chains and lost economies of scale. Increased defense spending and reshoring manufacturing boost labor-intensive sectors. Reduced technology transfer limits capital-augmenting innovations, raising labor share.

Extended healthy working years increase labor supply but biotech innovations are capital-intensive. Returns flow primarily to pharmaceutical companies, biotech investors, and IP holders rather than workers. Productivity gains from healthier workforce partially offset by capital concentration in biotech sector.

Low productivity growth reduces returns to capital investment. Declining business dynamism and limited innovation mean capital accumulation slows while labor markets remain relatively stable. Weak corporate profits and low investment rates increase labor's share of stagnant economic pie.

Green transition creates labor-intensive installation and maintenance jobs but also requires massive capital investment in renewable infrastructure. Effects roughly balance: increased employment in green sectors offset by capital intensity of energy transition technologies.

Major conflict destroys capital stock through direct warfare, infrastructure damage, and disrupted supply chains. Reconstruction prioritizes labor-intensive activities. Capital flight and asset destruction dramatically reduce capital base while surviving populations provide labor, substantially increasing labor share.

Massive mortality reduces labor supply but also destroys demand and economic activity. Capital stock remains relatively intact but underutilized. Historical precedent from Black Death shows surviving workers gain bargaining power. Labor scarcity increases wages relative to capital returns, raising labor share.

Winner-take-all dynamics and monopolistic concentration dramatically shift income to capital owners and technology oligarchs. Returns to capital dominate as AI platforms, data networks, and automation create extreme economies of scale. Labor share falls to historically low levels despite political resistance.

Baseline scenario with continuation of recent trends. Labor share has declined from ~65% in 1970s to ~60% globally today. Moderate technological progress, automation, and capital deepening continue gradual decline, balanced by service sector growth and some policy interventions maintaining rough stability.

Rapid job displacement without replacement dramatically reduces labor's bargaining power and employment rates. Returns flow to automation technology owners and capital. Even with UBI transfers, measured labor share (wages/GDP) falls as traditional employment collapses and capital income dominates.

Digital leapfrogging enables labor in developing nations to capture more value through direct global market access. Reduced capital requirements for service sector participation and remote work integration shift bargaining power toward workers. Technology cost reductions democratize access, increasing labor share especially in emerging economies.

Space industrialization is extremely capital-intensive requiring massive upfront investment in launch systems, orbital infrastructure, and asteroid mining equipment. Returns concentrate among aerospace companies and investors. While creating some high-skill jobs, the sector is fundamentally capital-dominant, reducing overall labor share.

AI-enabled authoritarianism could either suppress labor organizing and reduce wages, or maintain social stability through redistribution and state employment. Effects vary by regime but globally average to modest impact. Some authoritarian states may maintain higher labor share through state sector employment for political stability.

Nuclear stability avoids catastrophic destruction but doesn't directly determine capital-labor dynamics. Serves as background condition enabling other economic trends to proceed. Essentially neutral to baseline trajectory with continued gradual technological advancement and capital accumulation.

AI accelerates renewable technology breakthroughs in materials science, grid optimization, and energy storage. AI-driven efficiency gains reduce energy demand while optimizing renewable integration. However, increased compute power demands may partially offset gains.

Catastrophic climate impacts force emergency transition away from fossil fuels despite economic chaos. Survival imperatives override cost considerations. However, infrastructure destruction and resource conflicts may slow deployment rates.

Fragmented supply chains and reduced technology transfer slow renewable deployment. Competing spheres prioritize energy security through diverse sources including fossil fuels. Duplicated infrastructure and reduced economies of scale increase costs and slow transition.

Biotech advances primarily affect health and agriculture rather than energy systems directly. Increased longevity may modestly boost energy demand. Agricultural efficiency gains could free land for bioenergy but impact on renewable share remains limited.

Low growth and constrained investment limit capital available for renewable infrastructure buildout. Near-zero interest rates help but political gridlock prevents coordinated energy transition policies. Incumbent fossil fuel interests maintain influence during policy paralysis.

Massive coordinated investment and policy support drive rapid renewable deployment. Breakthrough cost reductions make renewables economically dominant. Grid transformation with advanced storage enables high penetration. Climate mitigation becomes central economic priority.

Major conflict destroys energy infrastructure and diverts resources to military production. Energy security concerns favor domestic fossil fuel production. International cooperation on climate collapses. Supply chain disruption slows renewable technology deployment.

Engineered pandemic causes massive economic disruption and mortality, collapsing investment in long-term infrastructure projects. However, reduced economic activity lowers total energy demand. Recovery prioritizes immediate needs over energy transition.

Tech oligopolies may invest heavily in renewables for corporate sustainability or profit motives. However, extreme inequality could reduce policy focus on public goods like climate action. Concentrated capital enables large-scale projects but political instability may hinder coordination.

Continued technological advancement and incremental policy improvements enable steady renewable deployment. Cost curves continue declining. Periodic setbacks slow but don't derail transition. International cooperation sufficient to maintain progress despite challenges.

Labor displacement reduces energy demand from reduced economic activity. However, automation itself requires substantial energy for computation and manufacturing. Policy focus shifts to social safety nets rather than energy transition. Net effect roughly neutral.

Developing nations bypass fossil fuel infrastructure, deploying distributed renewables and microgrids directly. Falling technology costs enable rapid adoption. Digital infrastructure requires less energy than traditional industrial development. Global renewable deployment accelerates.

Space-based solar power or orbital manufacturing could provide clean energy sources. Even without direct space energy, reduced launch costs enable better satellite monitoring and optimization of terrestrial renewable systems. High-value space manufacturing reduces terrestrial energy intensity.

Authoritarian regimes can mandate rapid renewable deployment without democratic constraints. However, they may prioritize control and fossil fuel resources for geopolitical leverage. China's current renewable leadership suggests net modest positive but variable by regime priorities.

Maintained nuclear deterrence prevents catastrophic conflict that would derail energy transition, but doesn't directly accelerate renewable deployment. Stability enables continued international cooperation and investment, producing baseline progression similar to historical trends.

AI dramatically accelerates genomics research, optimization of sequencing chemistry, and automation of laboratory processes. AI-designed enzymes and computational methods could reduce costs by orders of magnitude beyond current trajectories.

Cascading climate failures divert resources from basic research, disrupt supply chains for reagents and equipment, and cause brain drain from science. Progress stalls as societies focus on survival rather than technology development.

Fragmentation reduces economies of scale, duplicates research efforts, limits technology transfer, and restricts access to global supply chains. Multiple competing standards and reduced collaboration slow cost reductions significantly.

Direct focus on biotechnology breakthroughs drives massive investment in genomics infrastructure. Synthetic biology advances, improved sequencing chemistry, and widespread adoption create intense cost competition and technological leaps.

Low growth limits R&D investment, reduces market incentives for innovation, and slows infrastructure development. Debt burdens constrain both public and private funding for genomics technology advancement.

Green transition focuses resources elsewhere but maintains overall technological progress and international cooperation. Genomics advances continue on trend but aren't specifically accelerated or hindered by climate-focused investment.

Major conflict destroys infrastructure, kills scientists, disrupts supply chains, and redirects all resources to military applications. International scientific cooperation collapses. Genomics becomes fragmented and militarized with minimal civilian cost reduction.

Engineered pandemic devastates scientific workforce, disrupts global supply chains, and redirects biotech resources to emergency response. Recovery is slow and genomics research suffers from lack of investment and human capital loss.

Technology oligopolies invest heavily in genomics as part of biotech dominance. Winner-take-all dynamics drive aggressive cost reduction to capture market share. Concentrated capital enables massive economies of scale despite inequality concerns.

Continued incremental progress in sequencing technology follows historical cost reduction trends. Periodic disruptions are managed and international cooperation maintains technology development despite challenges.

Automation reduces labor costs in genomics laboratories and manufacturing, but economic disruption and reduced consumer purchasing power limit market growth. Technology advances but deployment is constrained by economic headwinds.

Universal digital access and global talent integration accelerates innovation. Developing nations contribute to genomics R&D, expanding the innovation base. Falling technology costs and distributed research create competitive pressure driving rapid cost reduction.

Space-based manufacturing could enable novel sequencing approaches in microgravity or provide ultra-pure materials. More importantly, economic boom from space industry funds extensive biotech R&D. Advanced materials from space reduce equipment costs.

Authoritarian regimes invest in genomics for surveillance and control purposes, driving some cost reduction. However, reduced scientific freedom, limited international collaboration, and focus on control rather than civilian applications moderates progress.

Nuclear stability maintains international order and allows continued scientific cooperation. Genomics research proceeds on normal trajectory without catastrophic disruption, but scenario doesn't specifically enhance or impede genomics cost reduction.

AI acceleration enables breakthrough space technologies including advanced robotics, autonomous systems, and AI-optimized manufacturing that dramatically reduce costs for orbital operations and enable profitable space ventures earlier than baseline.

Climate catastrophe redirects resources to urgent terrestrial adaptation and survival, but space-based solar power might receive emergency investment as energy solution. Mixed effects roughly cancel to baseline trajectory.

Competing spheres duplicate space programs inefficiently, restrict technology sharing, and reduce international cooperation on large space infrastructure projects. Trade barriers limit space commerce growth and fragment markets.

Extended healthy working years and improved productivity help general economy including space sector, but biotech doesn't directly accelerate space-specific capabilities. Marginal positive impact on baseline.

Low growth, limited investment capital, near-zero interest rates paradoxically hurt high-risk ventures. Stagnation reduces appetite for expensive space infrastructure despite potentially low borrowing costs. Minimal space development.

Massive investment in terrestrial renewables and storage might reduce urgency for space-based solar power, but general technological momentum and manufacturing capabilities could spillover positively. Roughly neutral overall.

Major war destroys capital, disrupts global supply chains, redirects resources to military/reconstruction, and creates risk environment hostile to long-term space investment. Space economy development severely curtailed.

Hundreds of millions dead, health systems overwhelmed, global trade disrupted, and massive economic contraction for decade-plus. Space industry development becomes extremely low priority during existential biological crisis.

Technology oligopolies with massive capital accumulation can fund high-risk space ventures. Winner-take-all dynamics favor few mega-corporations capable of space industrialization investments. Concentrated wealth enables ambitious space projects.

Baseline scenario with steady technological progress and manageable setbacks. Space industry develops incrementally through 2050s with some commercial operations but limited GDP contribution. Represents central tendency.

Labor displacement might paradoxically benefit space industry where automation advantages are clearest, but overall economic disruption and political instability from unemployment reduce investment capacity. Slightly below baseline.

Broader global participation and reduced development costs help general economy, but space industrialization requires massive physical capital beyond digital infrastructure. Modest positive spillover effects keep near baseline.

By definition, this scenario assumes breakthrough success in orbital manufacturing, asteroid mining, or space-based solar becoming cost-competitive. Thriving cislunar economy by 2040s creates substantial GDP contribution by 2050.

AI surveillance states prioritize social control over innovation and economic dynamism. Oppressive governance reduces risk-taking, international cooperation, and entrepreneurial space ventures. Some state-directed programs but limited commercial development.

Stability prevents catastrophic disruption but doesn't directly accelerate space development. Arms control and crisis management maintain baseline conditions for economic development including space sector.
